lg.l: The bearer of this letter is my friend,
Mr. Hermann Struck, for whose work as an artist I
have the greatest admiration. He will explain the
reason he wishes to see you, and anything that you
may be able to do for him I shall greatly appreciate.
Thank you very much for sending me the
etchings which I think are as pleasing as the subject
permitted you to make. There were not nine, but
eight and I have marked two of them as first and
second choice. Altogether, I think I would like
to have about twenty copies for the time being.
Should there be an unexpectedly large demand I
will ask for some more prints.
Meanwhile I thank you very much for the
charming way in which you have made the sittings
so pleasant and I would be obliged if you would
let me know to what extent I am indebted to you.
I thank you very much for your
letter and take pleasure in enclosing my check
for $2,500 and shall be very glad to receive
the plate and twenty five fifty copies.
of your kind letter, and the etchings which
are very nice, and which everybody seems to think
are not only fine work, but an excellent por¬
Will you be kind enough to send
me the plate at your convenience, and also
a bill or memorandum so that I can remit to
My sister joins in kind re-
gards to you, and Mrs. Struck.
I have your kind letter of
the 8th inst, and thank you for sending me
the plate. I want to take this opportunity,
however, to repeat that everybody is delight-
ed with the picture, and admire your work
$2000. for which I will be pleased to receive
With kind regards to you, and
The New Palestine for April 6th, the cover
of which was a reproduction of your painting, proved
to be so popular that we haven't a single copy left
in stock. I regret very much therefore that I cannot
send copies of the paper to the two persons you mention
in your note of May 8th. However, I am keeping your
note on my desk and should I be able to get hold of
two copies, I shall certainly send them out for you.
I trust that by this time you have received
I am enclosing herewith a receipt for $10
for the advertising of the Hotel Hadar-Harcarmel. I
have also forwarded your letter to Judge Rosenblatt.
Mr. Weisgal is very busy at present and
has been out of the office a good deal. He asks me
to say, however, that he will write to you within the
next few days with regard to the sketch which you were
I regret very much in not being able to see
you before my departure for Europe, but my list of ap¬
pointments is so heavy, and my time so short, that I
find myself overwhelmed with many pressing obligations.
I do want, however, to tell you how much I
appreciate your splendid etching of Mr. Mellon's Van der
Weyden - "Portrait of a Lady". It is truly a beautiful
piece of work, and you have indeed rendered a very soul¬
With all good wishes, believe me,
THE JEWISH ACADEMY OF ARTS AND SCIENCES

l.ORG: The Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences

lg.l: takes pleasure in informing you that you have been
duly elected a foreign member thereof.
A certificate to that effect will be
forwarded to you in due course.
THE JEWISH ACADEMY OF ARTS AND SCIENCES
I was very glad to hear from you again
in yours of the 10th July, and shall be only too
happy to do what I can for you in the matter to
which you refer. I well remember the etching of
the lady's portrait by Roger van der Weyden in
Mr. Mellon's collection. It is possible that
some of the etchings were filed away in New York,
and I have written asking them to go into the
matter, and let me hear from them at the earliest
opportunity. Immediately I receive their reply
I will communicate with you again.
I appreciate so much your charming
suggestion about seeing you in your home on the
slope of Mount Carmel. It is most unlikely that
I shall ever be in that neighborhood, but if I
ever am, nothing will give me greater pleasure
Meanwhile I trust you are very well,
